awd_titl_txt: Excited and Ground State Hydrogen Migration
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic and Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division and directed by Professor Matthew Platz, NSF funds are used to support undergraduate research at the University of Hawaii-Hilo (UHH).  The research incorporates synthetic organic chemistry, photochemistry, chemical analysis of reaction mixtures and chemical computations. This research tests the predictions of advanced theoretical methods in the description of a new photochemical reaction mechanism. The University of Hawaii Hilo (UH Hilo) consistently ranks among the most diverse four-year campuses in the nation.  This project provides a modern research experience to economically-challenged undergraduate students from historically underrepresented populations.  Through a collaborative relationship, UH Hilo undergraduates spend summer months at the Ohio State University developing skills in computational chemistry under the tutelage of Professor Christopher Hadad, an expert in the field of time-resolved, femtosecond measurements.

In Hilo, Hawaii, undergraduate students synthesize diazirines, diazo compounds and oxadiazolines, expose these compounds to monochromatic ultraviolet-visible radiation to generate carbene intermediates, and analyze the ratio of alkene products so produced as a function of excitation wavelength. The predictions of theory are confirmed if the ratio of alkene stereoisomers changes dramatically after a critical energy of exciting photons is realized. Through a collaborative relationship, UH Hilo undergraduates spend summer months at the Ohio State University developing skills in computational chemistry under the tutelage of Professor Christopher Hadad, an expert in the field. The students also participate in femtosecond time-resolved infrared experiments which measure the lifetimes and reactivities of carbenes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Hawai’i Hilo (UHH) is a comprehensive, regional university and is a primarily undergraduate institution. UHH does not offer the MSc nor the Ph.D. in chemistry, nor in any other Arts and Sciences disciplines. For most of its history, UHH was exclusively a teaching institution. In recent years, however, NSF EPSCoR, CREST, LSAMP and SSTEM investment, and the establishment of the Daniel K. Inouye College of Pharmacy have increased the STEM research footprint of the institution.

The Chronicle of Higher Education and US News and World Report consistently rank UHH as among the most diverse four-year campuses in the nation.  In Fall 2021, UH Hilo enrolled 1878 students of Asian/Pacific Islander ethnicity, 1066 Native Hawaiian students, 52 Hispanic, 763 Caucasian, 39 African American or Black, 36 American Indian or Alaskan Native, and 457 students of mixed race.  About half of all UH Hilo undergraduates are Pell eligible, and almost two thirds take less than 15 credit hours per semester. There is essentially no achievement gap between Caucasian and Native Hawaiian students, but the six-year graduation rate is concerning, just under 40%.

The development of human capital is the main outcome of this award. During the grant period the Platz Laboratory provided the only opportunity for undergraduate research involving organic synthesis, photochemistry, and computational chemistry at UHH. The PI worked shoulder to shoulder with undergraduates of unique diversity performing research in Hilo.

Over the past three years, 24 undergraduates worked in the Platz laboratory in Hilo, 19 women and 5 men. Thirteen of these students received NSF salary support at some point during their research. Two of the 24 students identify as part Native Hawaiians, one as Tahitian American, three as Filipino Americans, four as Native Americans, two as Mexican Americans, one as African American and three as Asian Americans. One former UHH student has successfully finished her first two years of graduate study in chemistry at the University of Washington, one is beginning graduate school in chemistry at the University of Washington, one has begun a Ph.D. in Chemistry this fall at Boston University, one has started study for a graduate degree in Education at UHH and two students have begun study at a College of Pharmacy. One former Platz UHH undergraduate is now working on vaccine development in the Goodrich Laboratory at Colorado State University.  The rest of the students decided to take  gap years before applying to graduate or medical school.

Chemicals, hardware and software obtained with NSF support will be available to large numbers of students in the instructional laboratories and will be used in a new course "Research methods in Chemistry" that will bring a research expeience into the undergraduate curriculum.
